Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates Dr. Fauci's statement on February 29th, suggesting that he said there was "nothing to worry about" and that the virus posed "no threat to the US public at large," which is an exaggeration of his actual remarks.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to back up its assertion about Dr. Fauci's statement on February 29th.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Dr. Fauci's statement on February 29th contradicts the advice and warnings he has given about COVID-19, which may be a problematic assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Dr. Fauci's remarks on February 29th were filled with caveats indicating that the situation could change, and he did not suggest that there was "nothing to worry about" or that the virus "posed no threat to the public."
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation to the claim that Dr. Fauci's statement on February 29th contradicts his overall advice and warnings about COVID-19, as his remarks were consistent with the evolving understanding of the virus at that time.
